com.nuance.android.vocalizer

Class VocalizerEngine

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.nuance.android.vocalizer.VocalizerEngine
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    android.media.AudioTrack.OnPlaybackPositionUpdateListener, com.nuance.android.vocalizer.internal.VocalizerInstallationListener

    public class VocalizerEngine
extends java.lang.Object
implements android.media.AudioTrack.OnPlaybackPositionUpdateListener, com.nuance.android.vocalizer.internal.VocalizerInstallationListener
    Class for interacting with the Vocalizer Expressive Text-to-Speech engine.

    Class Overview

    This is the main class for integrating the Nuance Vocalizer Expressive Text-to-Speech engine into your application. It provides methods to enumerate and load voices, speak text, stop playback, etc. By means of callback interfaces your application can be notified of certain events that will occur during the life-time of the engine, such as when it has started speaking text, or when a particular text mark has been reached.

    VocalizerEngine will also take care of managing and synchronizing with the device's audio output, although you can also request the engine to send you the audio samples of the speech synthesis and process them yourself.

    Your application can instantiate multiple instances of VocalizerEngine in case it needs, for example, to process text in different languages at the same time.

    Creation and Initialization of the Vocalizer Engine

    The VocalizerEngine is created by instantiating the class using its constructor. It is strongly recommended that this is done from the main UI thread. All callbacks coming from the engine to the registered listeners will be called in the context of the thread that instantiated the VocalizerEngine class.

    After the VocalizerEngine class has been instantiated you should immediately call its initialize() method. initialize() will look for the voices that your application holds in its assets folder, as well as other voices installed on your device and perform some basic initialization of the engine. Note that initialize() will not load any voice or initialize the audio hardware.

    Here is an example of how to initialize the Vocalizer Engine from an Android Activity: 

     public class MyActivity extends Activity implements VocalizerEngineListener {
      private VocalizerEngine ttsEngine=null;

      public void onCreate(Bundle savedInstanceState) {
           super.onCreate(savedInstanceState);
           setContentView(R.layout.main);

           ttsEngine=new VocalizerEngine(getApplicationContext());
           ttsEngine.setListener(this);

           ttsEngine.initialize();
      }

      public void onStateChanged(int newState) {
           if ( newState == VocalizerEngine.STATE_INITIALIZED ) {
             // Initialization has succeeded.
           }
           else if ( newState == VocalizerEngine.STATE_INIT_ERROR ) {
             // Initialization has failed.
           }
      }
 }

    Listening to engine status changes

    If you wish to monitor the state of the engine, you can use the setListener(VocalizerEngineListener) method and implement the VocalizerEngineListener interface. Here is an example: 
     public class MyActivity extends Activity implements VocalizerEngineListener {

      public void onCreate(Bundle savedInstanceState) {
           // ...

           vocalizerEngine.setListener(this);

           // Initialize engine
           // ...
      }

      public void onStateChanged(int newState) {
          if ( newState == VocalizerEngine.STATE_SPEAKING ) {
               // Engine is currently speaking
          }
          else if ( newState == VocalizerEngine.STATE_READY ) {
               // Engine is ready to speak.
          }
      }
 }

    Receiving callbacks on synthesis completion and end

    The engine's speak() method let's you assign an id to any text passed to the synthesizer. Assigning an id to a text is only mandatory if you want to be notified when that specific text has started to be spoken or when completed.

    The following example shows how you can use the VocalizerEngineListener interface to receive callbacks for text being synthesized: 

     public class MyActivity extends Activity implements VocalizerEngineListener {

      public void onCreate(Bundle savedInstanceState) {
           // ...
           vocalizerEngine.setListener(this);
           // ...
           vocalizer.speak("This is text 1", false, "text_1");
           vocalizer.speak("This is text 2", false, "text_2");
      }

      public void onSpeakElementStarted(String id) {
        Log.i("Debug", "onSpeakElementStarted: " + id);
      }

      public void onSpeakElementCompleted(String id) {
        Log.i("Debug", "onSpeakElementCompleted: " + id);
      }
 }

    The output would be like this: 

     onSpeakElementStarted: text_1
 onSpeakElementCompleted: text_1
 onSpeakElementStarted: text_2
 onSpeakElementCompleted: text_2

    Note that if stop() is called while a text is being synthesized you will not be called back indicating that the text has been completed.

    Receiving notifications for speech marks

    If you wish to receive more complex notifications during synthesis (such as bookmarks, text units, words or phonemes) you can implement the VocalizerSpeechMarkListener interface and register your implementation via the setSpeechMarkListener(VocalizerSpeechMarkListener) method.

    The sample application that ships with this SDK shows a concrete implementation of this functionality.

    Synchronously wait for synthesis to complete

    Sometimes you may want to synchronously wait for a particular text to be finished speaking. This can be accomplished through the VocalizerSpeechItem object returned by the speak method.

    Note that you should never block the main thread, so you must create your own thread in order for it to synchronously wait. The following example shows how to do this: 

     public void MyActivity extends Activity {

      private void speakSynch(String text) {

           final class ItemWaiter implements Runnable {
                VocalizerSpeechItem item;

                ItemWaiter(VocalizerSpeechItem i) {
                     item=i;
                }

                public void run() {
                     Log.i("Debug", "Waiting for item to complete...");
                     item.waitForComplete();
                     Log.i("Debug", "Item with ID: " + item.getId() + " has completed");
                }
           }

           VocalizerSpeechItem item=vocalizerEngine.speak("This is some text", false, "text_id");

           if ( item != null ) {
                new Thread(new ItemWaiter(item)).start();
           }
      }
 }
    Note that if stop() is called during synthesis, the threads synchronously waiting for the text to be completed by a call to VocalizerSpeechItem.waitForComplete() will be released.

    Controlling the Audio Playback

    The Vocalizer Engine provides several methods in order to control how the audio is streamed through the audio hardware.

    By default, the engine will pick the best audio settings for the current speech voice, but you can specify custom audio settings (in the form of sample rate and number of channels) through the setCustomAudioSettings method. Note that by specifying custom audio settings you're forcing the engine to re-sample the audio output buffers, and as a result there will be a higher CPU load. Therefore it is recommended to use the default audio settings.

    During playback you can pause audio by calling pause(). Note that while the audio is paused you will not receive any speech events, such as bookmarks, since these events are always synchronized with the audio. In order to resume playback, call resume()

    Controlling the Volume

    The Vocalizer Engine let's you control two types of volume: the speech voice, and the audio stream voice. The speech voice directly controls volume at which the audio samples for the current voice are generated. The speech volume can be set through the setSpeechVolume(int) method.

    In order to control the volume at which the audio hardware will play the generated audio samples use the setAudioOutputVolume(float, float), which also lets you control the left and right channels (balance) independently in case you're streaming in stereo.

    Note that it's ultimately up to the user to decide at which volume the sound will play. The user can, at any time, use the device's volume keys in order to set the device volume. It's therefore recommended to leave the speech and audio stream volumes to their default settings, and let the user pick the desired volume.

    Loading Speech Resources

    Vocalizer rule sets and user dictionaries can be loaded so that they are used during synthesis. These resources can be loaded as files or by directly passing its contents as a byte array. If loaded as files, they must be stored in the assets/vocalizer folder of your application.

    In order to load a rule set you can use the loadRuleSet(byte[]) or loadRuleSet(String) methods. To load a user dictionary, use the loadUserDictionary(byte[]) or loadUserDictionary(String) method.

    Beware that you're responsible for unloading the resources when they are no longer needed in order to save memory.

    The following example shows how to load and unload a user dictionary: 

     public class MyActivity extends Activity {

      // "Handle" to the loaded user dictionary
      private long userDictionary=-1;

      public void loadUserDictionary() {
           userDictionary=vocalizerEngine.loadUserDictionary("udct-eng");
      }

      public void unloadUserDictionary() {
           if ( userDictionary != -1 )
              vocalizerEngine.unloadResource(userDictionary);
      }
 }

    Getting the speech audio samples

    Sometimes it may be required for your application to receive the raw audio samples during synthesis, for example in order to save them to a file.

    This functionality can be accomplished through the setAudioOutputListener method of the vocalizer engine. When receiving audio samples you can tell the engine if you want the audio to still be streamed through the system audio hardware. In this case, you will receive the samples synchronized with the real audio output.

    The following example shows you how to save the audio samples to a file, while at the same time preventing the speech from being heard. 

     public class MyActivity extends Activity implements VocalizerAudioOutputListener {

      private BufferedOutputStream fileStream=null;

      public void onCreate(Bundle savedInstanceState) {
           // ...
           // Initialize engine

           // Tell the engine we are only interested in receiving the samples
           vocalizerEngine.setAudioOutputListener(this, true);

           // Create the file
           fileStream=new BufferedOutputStream(new FileOutputStream("file.raw"));
      }

      public void onAudioData(final VocalizerAudioSettings settings, final short[] audioData) {
           writeSamplesToFile(fileStream, audioData);
      }

      public void onDestroy() {
           super.onDestroy();

           if ( fileStream != null ) {
                fileStream.flush();
                fileStream.close();
           }
      }
 }

    The Vocalizer Sample Application

    Most of the functionality provided by the Vocalizer Engine is demonstrated in the Vocalizer Sample application that ships with this SDK. The sample shows you how to:
    1. Initialize and release the speech engine
    2. Load a voice from a list of available voices (loacated in the assets/vocalizer folder)
    3. Change the volume, pitch and rate of the voice
    4. Receive audio samples during synthesis, which are shown in an oscilloscope.
    5. Receive phonemes during synthesis in order to show simple lip-synch.
    6. Receive callbacks for word markers, which are highlighted on the screen and synchronized with the real audio.
    7. Pause/Resume speech output.
    8. Listen for engine state changes.
    9. Receive callbacks when text is started or done speaking.
    10. Handle activity re-creation and preserve the state of the engine and current synthesis.
    11. Obfuscate the code using ProGuard
    Since:
    1.0

                                   boolean onlySamples)
        Register a listener that will receive audio samples during synthesis.
        Parameters:
        listener - the listener to receive callbacks
        onlySamples - true if you're only interested in the audio samples, false if the audio samples should still be sent to the audio output stream.
        See Also:
        VocalizerAudioOutputListener

      • setCustomAudioSettings

        public void setCustomAudioSettings(VocalizerAudioSettings settings)
        Specifies custom audio output settings (sample rate and number of channels). The engine will initialize the audio output stream with the given output settings. Note that this will cause the voice audio samples to be re-sampled during playback, and therefore there may be some quality loss. Re-sampling will also add additional overhead and increase CPU usage.
        Parameters:
        settings - the desired audio output settings, pass null to return to the default audio settings.
        See Also:
        VocalizerAudioSettings

      • setAudioOutputVolume

        public void setAudioOutputVolume(float left,
                                 float right)
        Sets the volume of the audio output stream.
        Parameters:
        left - the left channel volume (from 0f to 1.0f)
        right - the right channel volume (from 0f to 1.0f)

      • initialize

        public void initialize()
        Initializes the Vocalizer Engine. This process involves setting up the Text-to-Speech engine, but it does not load any voice. Note that the initialization process is asynchronous. You must wait until the initialization of the engine has completed before you can make any calls to it.
        See Also:
        release(), setListener(VocalizerEngineListener)

      • release

        public void release()
        Releases the Vocalizer Engine. This releases all the resources allocated by the engine, and unloads the voice. Once this method has been invoked, the engine is set to an uninitialized state, and invoking methods of the engine will fail. This method is synchronous.
        See Also:
        initialize()

      • reload

        public boolean reload()
        Forces a complete release and re-initialization of the engine. The configuration of the engine is preserved across a re-initialization.

        This method is used internally whenever the engine detects that new voices are available in the system. It is not recommended that third party applications use this.

        The synthesis of the current item will be stopped and the speech queue will be cleaned as part of the reloading process.

        Note that the currently registered engine listener will not receive STATE_UNINITIALIZED and STATE_INITIALIZED state changes as part of the reloading process. On the other hand, if re-initialization fails, the listener will receive the STATE_INIT_ERROR status change.

        This method is asynchronous.

        Returns:
        whether or not the reloading process has started.
        See Also:
        initialize(), release()

      • speak

        public VocalizerSpeechItem speak(java.lang.String text,
                                 boolean flush,
                                 java.lang.String textId)
        Speaks the given text. If no synthesis is currently in progress the text will be spoken immediately, otherwise it will be queued.
        Parameters:
        text - the text to synthesize
        flush - whether any pending queued text should be flushed (removed from the queue). This is equivalent to calling stop()
        textId - an identifier of the text. This is used to identify this speech item when VocalizerEngineListener.onSpeakElementCompleted(String) or VocalizerEngineListener.onSpeakElementStarted(String) are invoked. If you're not interested in receiving notifications for this speech item, pass null.
        Returns:
        VocalizerSpeechItem that wraps information about this speech item. null if there has been a problem trying to synthesize the text (most likely the engine is not yet initialized or the method was called from a wrong thread).

      • stop

        public boolean stop()
        Stops the current synthesis. Audio output is immediately stopped, and the text queue is cleared. This is a synchronous method.
        Returns:
        true if the stop was successful, false otherwise.

      • pause

        public boolean pause()
        Pauses the audio playback.
        Returns:
        true if the audio output was successfully paused

      • resume

        public boolean resume()
        Resumes audio playback if previously paused.
        Returns:
        true if the audio playback was paused and has been successfully resumed.

      • setAudioStream

        public void setAudioStream(int stream)
        Sets the system audio channel that will be used to stream the audio. This is one of the streams provided by AudioManager. By default the audio is streamed using AudioManager.STREAM_MUSIC
        Parameters:

      • onPeriodicNotification

        public void onPeriodicNotification(android.media.AudioTrack track)
        For internal use only. Called periodically by the audio output stream in order to inform of the current playback position. This method is responsible for dispatching the speech mark events that have been scheduled. This ensures that speech mark events are synchronized with the real audio output.
        Specified by:
        onPeriodicNotification in interface android.media.AudioTrack.OnPlaybackPositionUpdateListener

      • loadUserDictionary

        public long loadUserDictionary(java.lang.String fileName)
        Loads a user dictionary to be used while synthesizing speech. The dictionary must be in a file contained in the assets/vocalizer folder of the application.
        Parameters:
        fileName - the name of the file that contains the user dictionary. You must supply the name without an extension.
        Returns:
        the handle to the loaded resource. You must pass this handle to unloadResource in order to unload the resource. -1 if the resource could not be loaded.

      • loadUserDictionary

        public long loadUserDictionary(byte[] data)
        Loads a user dictionary to be used while synthesizing speech.
        Parameters:
        data - a buffer containing the user dictionary to be loaded.
        Returns:
        the handle to the loaded resource. You must pass this handle to unloadResource in order to unload the resource. -1 if the resource could not be loaded.

        Parameters:
        handle - the handle to the loaded resource.
        Returns:
        true if the resource was successfully unloaded, false if otherwise.

      • getSortedVoiceList

        public VocalizerVoice[] getSortedVoiceList(java.lang.String voiceName,
                                           java.lang.String language,
                                           int sampleRate)
        Utility function to sort the voices according to the given criteria.
        Parameters:
        voiceName - the name of the voice. Pass null if you are not interested in any voice name in particular.
        language - the language of the voice. Pass null if you are not interested in any language in particular.
        sampleRate - the sample rate of the voice. Pass 0 if you are not interested in any sample rate in particular.
        Returns:
        the voice list sorted by the given criteria.

      • setSpeechVolume

        public void setSpeechVolume(int vol)

        See Also:

        Parameters:
        rate - the rate of the voice in the range of 50 to 400. 100 is the default.

      • setSpeechReadMode

        public void setSpeechReadMode(int param)
        Sets the read mode to be used for synthesizing text. The read mode determines the way in which the Text-to-Speech engine will split the input text into text units. Each text unit will then be separately processed and pronounced.
        Parameters:
        param - the read mode
        See Also:
        READMODE_SENT, READMODE_CHAR, READMODE_WORD

      • getSpeechReadMode

        public int getSpeechReadMode()
        Gets the current read mode. If this method is called before initialization, the default setting will be returned.
        Returns:
        the current read mode. READMODE_SENT is the default.
        See Also:
        DEFAULT_READMODE

      • setSpeechWaitFactor

        public void setSpeechWaitFactor(int param)
        Sets the wait period (silence) inserted between two text units (e.g. sentences). Each unit is equivalent to 200ms of silence.
        Parameters:
        param - the wait period, in the range of 0 to 9.

      • getSpeechWaitFactor

        public int getSpeechWaitFactor()
        Gets the wait period (silence) inserted between two text units (e.g. sentences). If this method is called before initialization, the default setting will be returned.
        Returns:
        the current wait period, in the range of 0 to 9. 1 is the default.
        See Also:
        DEFAULT_WAIT_FACTOR

      • setAutoReinitialize

        public void setAutoReinitialize(boolean flag)
        Sets whether or not the Vocalizer Engine will automatically re-initialize when it detects that the list of available voices has changed. The list can change, for example, as a result of a new application containing voices being installed in the system, or as a result of an application being removed.

        Note that after re-initialization the configuration of the engine will be preserved. This means that the same voice will be loaded (if it's still available), and that the speech rate, pitch and other speaking properties are the same.

        The only noticeable side-effect of automatic re-initialization is that the item that is currently speaking will be stopped, and the speech queue will be cleared. During the re-initialization process all calls to the Vocalizer Engine will be ignored or fail. Note that during re-initialization you will not receive STATE_UNINITIALIZED and STATE_INITIALIZED state changes. If re-initialization fails, however, you will receive the STATE_INIT_ERROR state change.

        If your application does not support the addition of new voices as separate application packages, disable auto initialization. By default, this is enabled.

        Parameters:
        flag -
